results.title: Laser safety
results.creator_credit: Barry Pollack and University of California, Los Angeles
results.brief_description: Introduces the laser, illustrating the properties which make it useful, but explaining that it can be harmful to biological tissue. Demonstrates safety measures to prevent injury to eyes and skin.

results.title: Laser
results.brief_description: Light Amplification of Stimulated Emission of Radiation: this is the laser, the new wonder tool that can bore holes in steel, perform delicate eye operations and carry thousands of simultaneous telephone conversations and television channels. Communications with men on the moon may well be by means of a laser beam, and there is speculation about their use as “death rays” to bring down missiles in flight.

results.title: Laplanders
results.brief_description: Photographed by Swedish cameraman and film producer Arne Sucksdorff, this documentary observes the activities of the reindeer-tending Laplanders of northern Scandinavia. We see a family packing up from the mountainous summer fishing camp and crossing the high country moors with pack reindeers. When they reach their home the herd reindeers are gathered and many of the males slaughtered, every part of the body being used for food, shelter, clothing and implements. Three generations of the one family are shown.

results.title: Language of design
results.brief_description: Illustrates how Australian textile designers are finding inspiration from the local scene. Samples of sea shells, driftwood, dead twigs from a tea-tree, and other such mateerials collected on the Australian beach, are used in the studio to provide motifs for typically Australian textile designs. A series of such designs are effectively displayed by artistically draped samples.

results.title: Language and learning: talking and literature
results.creator_credit: Caroline Pick, David Seligman, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description:
Notes the responses of two groups of tertiary students to a piece of literature and emphasises the importance of discussion in the formulation of ideas and problem solving.
Suitable for tertiary levels.

results.title: Landslides
results.brief_description: Landslides takes us on a breathtaking journey of discovery, into and through the human body, under the ground, into the outback, into the air, into outer space. It provides visceral shock as it probes body tissues and spaces, and cerebral delight as it weaves intriguingly around its central theme.

results.title: Landscape in stamps
results.creator_credit: Michael Reeves, Tom Williamson and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description: Poetry, music and the detail of postage stamps are combined to produce an essentially impressionistic view of New Zealand’s social and physical landscape. A new direction of stamp concept.

results.title: Landscape as Character
results.brief_description: The Australian landscape is never just a setting. It’s meditative, motivational and menacing; a character that empowers, intimidates and inspires. This artwork examines how representations of Australian landscapes have evolved from being dominated by the Outback to the suburbs and cities.

constellations_primary.name: Landscape as character
constellations_primary.description: The landscape is often a character in Australian films. Usually, it's a villain that represents our problematic national character and is increasingly used to challenge our troubled history and explore our evolving identities.

results.description:
Australia’s First Peoples are connected to Country through thousands of generations of kinship ties. We derive our identity, culture, law and knowledge from Country – something we express and uphold through moving image storytelling. Through the screen, we’re able to tell our story of survival against the violence of colonisation, ensuring our connection and re-connection to Country endures from the past to today.

The Australian landscape is never just a setting. It’s meditative, motivational and menacing; a character that empowers, intimidates and inspires. For years, the Outback has dominated Australian screen stories, but representations have sprawled into the suburbs and cities, creating compelling and complex characters on our screens.
description_for_label:
